title: L’ombre des hommes / Human Shadows
intro_text: For the second time after Mauthausen in 2006, Seiji Kimoto took the risk to exhibit his series "Power and Powerlessness" in a former concentration camp. From April 18 to December 23 in 2015, his sculptures were on display at the Centre Européen du Résistant Déporté (CERD) and the whole area of the "Struthof", the site of the former concentration camp Natzweiler in the French Vosges mountains. His exhibition "L'ombre des hommes" was part of a group exhibition of various artists entitled "70 ans / 70 œuvres", held at the occasion of the 70th anniversary of the abandonment of the concentration camp.

body_text:
The in-between ceremony of the exhibition took place at the national ceremony of remembrance on June 20, 2015. The event was opened by the Director of the CERD, Frédérique Neau-Dufour. Saarland Minister Ulrich Commerçon gave a brief word of welcome. An introduction to Seiji Kimoto's exhibition "L'ombre des hommes" was given by the former Hessian Interior Minister Gerhard Bökel.

At a place of unspeakable terror, Bökel said, Kimoto's works remind us of the people who became victims here. Not only of their physical and mental anguish, but also of their hopes and their strength to resist. And while his sculptures reiterated one theme: the moral superiority of the powerless, rooted deep inside, they could be understood as salute to resistance. Immediately following the speeches was the wake ceremony with the passing on of the flame of remembrance.
